thread.title: Vols have lived up to Rick Barnes' preseason prediction
thread.title_full: Vols have lived up to Rick Barnes' preseason prediction

title: Vols have lived up to Rick Barnes' preseason prediction
text:
After Tennessee's 90-70 win over Missouri on Saturday, Rick Barnes reiterated a point he first made way back in October: His second set of Vols, even in the preseason, were already better than his first at any point last season. 
They were then, they are now. 
Barnes said his second squad was deeper and more athletic, much better defensively and much more balanced. 
He was asked during his weekly press conference on Monday to expand on that presesaon prediction, diving into where his team has met his expectations and where they've fallen short. 
"We have fallen short when we felt like we were moving ahead and (then) we would go backwards," Barnes said. "It would be fundamental things where you would think guys were getting it defensively and then they didn’t. 
"I think at times when we have fallen short our maturity has shown up. I think there are a lot of people that think that." 
(Want the latest scoop on Tennessee football and basketball? Make sure you're in the loop — take five seconds to sign up for our FREE Vols newsletter now!) 
Tennessee (15-12, 7-7 SEC), which hosts Vanderbilt (14-13, 7-7) on Wednesday (TV: SEC Network, 6:30 p.m.) at Thompson-Boling Arena, has spent the last three weeks in the NCAA Tournament bubble conversation despite losing five games this season in which it led by at least 13 points. 
Closing games has exposed the sometimes lacking maturity of a young basketball team, one that gets 47.8 percent of its total scoring and 46.9 percent of total minutes played from freshmen. 
"Right now one question (will be) how do we handle this, coming down the stretch?" Barnes asked of the regular season's final four games. "It will be interesting, because some of these guys are a year removed from high school. Stakes are obviously bigger now than they have ever been involved with. 
"It will be interesting to see how they respond. I hope they can just take care of the process and go out and just do what we talked about. 
The Vols have improved defensively, as their coach said they would, giving up 73.5 points per game this season after giving up 75.2 per game in 2015-16. 
"We are a better overall defensive team," Barnes said, "even though we are not consistent enough." 
Kevin Punter led Tennessee in scoring last season at 22.2 points per game, a full 10 points better per night than Armani Moore , second highest on the team at 12.2. Senior guard Robert Hubbs leads the current Vols at 14.3 points per game, but freshman forward Grant Williams is closing in at 12.8. 
"Where we were different a year ago is that we can score inside," Barnes said of this team, which works through Hubbs, Williams and sophomore forward Admiral Schofield (8.1 points per game) to play inside-out basketball. "We really struggled to score there (last season)." 
Seven different players on this deeper roster of Vols have led the team in scoring in games this season. For what's believed to be the first time in program history, four different freshmen recorded 20 or more points in a game through the first 10 games on schedule. Six players in total have scored 20 or more in a game. 
"We have more guys that can have big nights for us," Barnes said. "Last year we had a couple of guys that did that, but I think consistently we have more guys that can do that now." 
How this team will ultimately be judged, though, is how it finishes the season. Whether it finds a way to defy odds and earn a berth in the NCAA Tournament, has to settle for an NIT bid or, like last season, has no postseason at all after the SEC Tournament in Nashville. 
"We have to continue to get better," Barnes said, "but we are better than we were a year ago."
